body: @john-bodley you're right. I ended up describing in "after" the workflow once we remove the dataframe cache.
Great work. Is this PR merged yet ?
can this be closed?

@mahendra: I verified the changes and all looks good. Can you rebase and update Alembic revision for the migration script?

@mistercrunch: Can we merge this PR into master once the migration db script revision updated?
+1 the chart class.

@villebro: I tried to verify this PR fix, now both preview and sqllab run query throws the following exception

2019-03-16 14:25:34,661:ERROR:root:'utf-8' codec can't decode byte 0xac in position 0: invalid start byte
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "/Users/muru/muru-superset/superset/views/core.py", line 2613, in sql_json
    encoding=None,
  File "/Users/muru/muru-superset/venv367/lib/python3.6/site-packages/simplejson/__init__.py", line 399, in dumps
    **kw).encode(obj)
  File "/Users/muru/muru-superset/venv367/lib/python3.6/site-packages/simplejson/encoder.py", line 296, in encode
    chunks = self.iterencode(o, _one_shot=True)
  File "/Users/muru/muru-superset/venv367/lib/python3.6/site-packages/simplejson/encoder.py", line 378, in iterencode
    return _iterencode(o, 0)
  File "/Users/muru/muru-superset/superset/utils/core.py", line 378, in pessimistic_json_iso_dttm_ser
    return json_iso_dttm_ser(obj, pessimistic=True)
  File "/Users/muru/muru-superset/superset/utils/core.py", line 360, in json_iso_dttm_ser
    val = base_json_conv(obj)
  File "/Users/muru/muru-superset/superset/utils/core.py", line 344, in base_json_conv
    return str(obj.tobytes(), 'utf8')
UnicodeDecodeError: 'utf-8' codec can't decode byte 0xac in position 0: invalid start byte

You may be seeing this `ImportError` because you are on `pandas  24.0.0`. The legacy datetime API is removed and replaced with another. I and a few others are investigating that issue atm. But for now, check to ensure you are on the correct version of `pandas`.

What's the output of:

`pandas --version`?
[here it is in the code](https://github.com/apache/incubator-superset/blob/d308c842f9fa3ffa4a1887e43a0757f24edf6cf5/setup.py#L91)
Ok let's reopen #6981 and take another stab at this. Any additional info you can give (postgres version, create table script, sample data that throws the error etc) will help track down the problem.
@kristw hey dude, I haven't gotten the answer to this question and why u close this issue?
Run `pip install pandas==0.23.1` and try again.

where I can enable following option

Make sure these boxes are checked before submitting your issue - thank you!

  I have checked the superset logs for python stacktraces and included it here as text if any
  I have reproduced the issue with at least the latest released version of superset
  I have checked the issue tracker for the same issue and I haven't found one similar
My apology. I misunstood while triaging the issues. Please feel free to reopen if this happens.
I also ran into the issue and had to alter `type` to accept more than 32 chars. This should be fixed. Does someone know where the database schema is stored in the repo? Then I can create a PR.

> `package-lock.json` is auto-generated by `npm`. Your changes will be overridden next time we change dependency. I would suggest removing it from this PR.

Done, thanks for the tip.
Did you test that all the altered links work? Some static/doc website still don't support https sometimes...
I'm wondering if [instead of the warning], we should match the behavior expected by the user, which to me is the "Google Docs" behavior.
Agreed, I've been struggling to get `npm link` to work properly in my dev env. Planning on sorting this out soonish. In the meantime if someone else wants to take this on, it's up for grabs.

Here's how it goes:
https://github.com/apache/incubator-superset/blob/b5d03c85c578bd12bfb99446a54543bd029361ad/superset/models/core.py#L800-L820
The fix in the PR above can be used as a workaround while we fix it in the visualization plugin.

Have you tried setting the conf flag `ENABLE_PROXY_FIX = True` ?

For context, here's what it does:
https://github.com/apache/incubator-superset/blob/3ae02d1a542ed66522f6a0a51433490e7da9ea30/superset/__init__.py#L162

http://werkzeug.pocoo.org/docs/0.14/contrib/fixers/#werkzeug.contrib.fixers.ProxyFix

Seems this seems to come up quite a bit, I was wondering to myself "should we make this the default"? 

It appears the answer is no :(. From the docs: "Do not use this middleware in non-proxy setups for security reasons."
"Validation" in what context? In the broad sense of the term it's very endpoint-specific...

> Did you test that all the altered links work? Some static/doc website still don't support https sometimes...

I tested all, manually. I did not change the http links when the website did not accept https. I also did not change the Apache http links, even though apache.org supports https, because the official licence text still points to the http:// address

The time filter is limited to what it does (each chart defines the column it uses for time, and applies the dashboard's filtering event on that column)

To work around this, it's possible to:
* design a chart that does not listen to any time filtering events http://superset.apache.org/faq.html#how-to-add-dynamic-filters-to-a-dashboard
* use a normal filter instead of your time filter 
* add columns/expressions in your database that may help in using simpler filters (say something like days_since_customer_joined)

About (3), people have been using this behavior to implement cascading filters. Though I understand it probably shouldn't be the default.

I think adding a new option "Receive filtering events from other filter boxes" that has a default of False, but is set to True for all existing Filter Box (for backwards compatibility reasons) seems reasonable.
Thank you for the quick reply @mistercrunch . But this does not solve my problem. Please let me know if there is anything I can do to customize the code.

I'm not sure if I understand (2) ? Do you mean not having a time filter set by default? The danger is the full table scan can be pretty brutal depending on the table and database engine. For partitioned tables in Presto it's good to try to limit user to scan only a few partitions to fill in these values.

By validation I meant, 

For example: a column named Email of table User has type of string in DB. And the front-end will uses regex or etc. to make sure and validate that the user doesn't enter anything other than a valid email address.  

And my question was does this validation process also being applied somewhere on the backend to make sure if the API's POST Request's argument is any string rather than a valid email address, the endpoint will not allow this to be saved into Database? 

thanks
Is this supposed to be fixed in #6765?
Hi @wushenchao , do you plan to reopen it? This is a great feature.

> Hi @wushenchao , do you plan to reopen it? This is a great feature.

![屏幕快照 2019-03-19 上午9 33 02](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/8774296/54574116-02f1e580-4a2a-11e9-8a87-86f8ec20c5f6.png)

Here, I don't know how to do use react, if you have a good idea, please let me know, thank you

I'm thinking Google Docs is where this UI interaction became more popular (editing the title). In Microsoft Office you would "save as" to change the filename, creating dups, but in GDocs you would go and edit the title right there in place, and it would always autosave. I guess it's different in GDocs as it always auto-saves and keeps track of history. 

So currently, does editing the title just saves the title to the current sliceId, or does it saves all the formData that might have changed?

@tino-247 were you able to fix it.

@villebro: Yes that's correct. I think, instead of displaying content of the binary data we should simply say "binary data" or something similar text. In superset released version 0.28.1, preview mode shows "Unserializable [<class 'memoryview'>]" for bytea column without any error. The issue is the user should able to perform select * from table (table contains bytea column) especially if the table has lot of columns.

Thanks for the tip. It seems to have solved this problem, or at least I can see the headers and I'm facing another one with Knox keystores now.

Since this is about [XFF-related headers](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/HTTP/Headers/X-Forwarded-For), it makes sense that this is used only when forwarding is needed (e.g. when proxying, like my case with Knox). I was tempted to say that "fix" in the name is misleading, as this is a valid and seemingly long-standing configuration option, but than I saw that in werkzeug it is under contrib.fixers, so probably that would be a better place for such a discussion.

Probably can use `deck.gl` instead

@mistercrunch another issue, the new filters break with filter charts on druid datasources if you don't select a metric in your filter. Metric is now not a required field, and it seems sqla datasources don't require you to have a metric, but filter boxes on druid datasource will break without a metric with `list index out of range`
```
File "superset/connectors/druid/models.py", line 1150, in run_query
    order_by = list(qry['aggregations'].keys())[0]
IndexError: list index out of range
```
Because the metric field wasn't migrated and is null, existing filter boxes on druid datasources are broken. Can we also add tests for this case? 
cc @graceguo-supercat
@villebro: I verified the changes and it worked in preview and run query modes. 👍
replaced with #7065

@mistercrunch currently editing the title saves the title and all of the form data to the slice. We could remove this and make it more like dashboard where editing the title just saves the title on the chart, but I'm not sure how attached people are to the current functionality, we'd need to message the change clearly so people don't think they are saving and lose work. 

One nice thing about a warning is it lets you know you are going to save something before you do, which is a problem we'd still have if we kept the save just on title.
